MoneyBeat » Europe http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat Up-to-the-minute news and analysis on deals, markets and finance around the world. Fri, 13 May 2016 07:13:10 +0000 en-US hourly 1 http://wordpress.org/?v=3.9.3 copyright © 2016 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. WSJ: MoneyBeat http://online.wsj.com/img/wsj_rss_logo.png http://online.wsj.com/ U.K. Set For Sterling Volatility Regardless of Brexit Referendum Result http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/u-k-set-for-sterling-volatility-regardless-of-brexit-referendum-result/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/u-k-set-for-sterling-volatility-regardless-of-brexit-referendum-result/#comments Thu, 12 May 2016 16:10:08 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49557 The Bank of England has issued its clearest warning yet of the consequences should the U.K. vote to leave the European Union in six weeks’ time.

Whether that happens or not, you can bet on one outcome: volatility for the pound.

Sterling rose by over 0.6% against the dollar following the Bank of England’s press conference on Thursday, at which it announced another unanimous decision to hold interest rates. By late afternoon, it was up by only around 0.10% at $1.44.

The BOE’s sterling exchange rate index, which tracks the average strength of the pound against a basket of other currencies, has declined by around 9% since its peak in November.

On Thursday, the central bank said that around half of that dip is due to the uncertainty surrounding the referendum on June 23.

That suggests the currency is much weaker than it would have been without the prospect of this vote, meaning that it could snap higher if the U.K. votes to remain.

[wsj-responsive-image P="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ562_BOEPOU_P_20160512092132.jpg" J="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ562_BOEPOU_J_20160512092132.jpg" M="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ562_BOEPOU_M_20160512092132.jpg" caption="" credit="" placement="Inline" suppressEnlarge="false" ]

Working out precisely how much of the recent fall in the pound is down to the referendum is a difficult task, but it matters enormously for how volatile the currency will be around the June 23 vote.

After its own calculations, the BOE issued a range of forecasts, based on different estimates of what proportion of the currency’s recent decline is down to the shadow cast by the referendum.

If all the fall since November was caused entirely by the referendum, the BOE suggests sterling would end the year down by just 1.2%, if the U.K votes to remain. That implies a significant rise in the pound once the uncertainty is lifted.

But if worries about the referendum haven’t actually had a major impact on the pound, and the decline has been due to other factors — like signs of a slight economic slowdown — then the Bank estimates that the pound would end the year 10.7% lower than it began. That’s if the British vote to stay in the European Union.

The gap between a decline of 1.2% and one of 10.7% is a large one for the foreign exchange market. It also impacts the BOE’s forecasts for inflation, with a strengthening pound meaning lower prices for goods from abroad.

If the BOE is right to attribute half of sterling’s decline over the last six months to the referendum, and the U.K. votes to remain, that 4.5% decline should reverse pretty quickly.

But what happens to the pound if the U.K. votes to leave? Sterling is forecast to slump.

Governor Mark Carney wouldn’t be drawn on a precise estimate of the potential decline in the pound, accept to say that it “would fall further, perhaps sharply.”

Analyst estimates on how much the British currency would depreciate in the case of a so-called Brexit have run as high as 20%.

Whatever happens, sterling seems likely to be volatile over the next two months, especially on June 24.

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/u-k-set-for-sterling-volatility-regardless-of-brexit-referendum-result/feed/ 0 What You Need to Know About Brexit and Finance http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/what-you-need-to-know-about-brexit-and-finance/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/what-you-need-to-know-about-brexit-and-finance/#comments Thu, 12 May 2016 14:44:40 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49565 This story first appeared on WSJ City: Fast, fact-packed updates on financial news impacting London and beyond. Made for mobile. Download for iPhone.

[wsj-responsive-image P="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ571_Brexit_P_20160512094727.jpg" J="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ571_Brexit_J_20160512094727.jpg" M="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ571_Brexit_M_20160512094727.jpg" caption="London Mayor Boris Johnson addresses supporters during a rally for the 'Vote Leave' campaign" credit="Getty Images" placement="Inline" suppressEnlarge="false" ]

London is one of the world’s largest financial hubs, priding itself on being the gateway between the U.S. and Europe (and Asia). But what happens if the U.K. decides to leave the European Union? How will this affect bankers and fund managers?

Lots is unknown, of course, and while estimates are being made by both sides on the cost to the economy, to jobs and competitiveness, those estimates vary widely. So what do we really know?

First, what is the EEA and why does it matter to this debate?

The European Economic Area is the glue that binds the European Union together. It allows free movement of people and trade throughout the 28 EU member states (plus a few honorary extras).

So it’s like having a business passport?

Right. Being in the EEA allows financial firms the ability to work in European member states without needing local authorization from every single local regulator. If you’re authorized in one market, you’re authorized in all.

According to the European Banking Authority, over 2,000 U.K. investment firms have outbound passporting rights.

Passporting rules have helped London grow as a financial services hub. It makes life easier if you can offer a host of cross-border services from one location.

What happens in the event of a Brexit?

In the event of a vote to Leave, there are two main scenarios. The U.K. could end up leaving the EEA entirely, and would then have to broker bi-lateral relationships that govern its relationship with the EU, similar to Switzerland’s relationship.

The alternative is that it stays part of the EEA, and therefore remains subject to EU regulations but has no say on how they are formed. This is similar to the relationship Norway and Iceland have with Europe.

What would happen to banks and fund managers?

There are a whole host of services that will be affected; who you can lend to, who you can market to, even who you can advise.

If the U.K. left the EEA, a bank or fund manager would have to gain local licences for all countries they wished to do business in. If they want a new passport for the EEA, they may also have to move the bulk of the relevant business to an EEA jurisdiction in order to qualify.

However, there are a number of areas where, if a non-EEA country has similar rules, then European legislators can permit business to continue without a sizable disruption.

For example, European regulation for fund managers can be extended to non-EEA managers, as long as they adhere to the existing rules, and get permission from a regulator in the EEA.

So there is a chance things can just continue as normal?

Well. If the U.K. promises to keep the same regulations, many problems may be avoided.

However, the U.K. has always been keen to tailor laws to suit its financial sector. It has recently fought the EU on issues such as bonuses, trading taxes, and clearing rules for pension schemes. If the U.K. begins to change its own financial regulation, this may make it harder to convince the EU to keep things the way they are.

There are also areas where rules for non-EEA states have not been sorted out, such as deposit taking or custody services.

There’s also the problem of disputes. If the fund manager did receive a non-EEA passport, any legal dispute with investors in the EEA would have to be heard and settled in an EEA law court, not the U.K.

What about how you make a trade? Surely that won’t change?

At present, a large amount of euro-denominated trades are cleared in London.

Following Brexit, the European Commission could force all euro-denominated trades to be cleared and settled in the eurozone.

Last year the U.K. won a legal battle against the ECB after the EU general court found that the ECB did not have the “competence necessary to regulate the activity of securities clearing systems.”

At the time, the ECB said it would look into ways of challenging the ruling. Brexit might prove a good opportunity to do that.

Is it a big deal if clearing houses are moved?

That depends. Clearing houses are increasingly important parts of the financial plumbing, acting as a middle man between trades, holding collateral in case one side of the trade goes bust. Think of them as shock absorbers.

London is home to some of the biggest clearing houses, including facilities operated by the London Stock Exchange, Intercontinental Exchange and CME. They are currently allowed to offer clearing services for customers across the EEA and in euro-denominated products. In the case of Brexit, U.K. clearing houses could only provide services within the EEA if they are subject to rules deemed equivalent to those in the EEA. Getting such approval would not be an overnight process.

There is also insolvency law to consider. If a buyer or seller goes bust and their trades are unsettled, then the clearing house’s national bankruptcy law comes into play when deciding who gets re-paid. The U.K. law is seen as one of the most favorable to lenders, German or French law less so.

Will lots of jobs have to move from London to the EU?

Some people think so. U.K. Treasury chief George Osborne, a leading figure in the campaign against Brexit, has warned there could be “tens of thousands” of potential job losses.

Xavier Rolet, head of the London Stock Exchange, has said up to 100,000 jobs could be lost from London’s financial sector. HSBC has said it might shift 1,000 staff to Paris in the event of a Brexit.

Some estimates seem high. There are currently around 360,000 employed in financial services in London, as of 2014, according to the Office for National Statistics.

However, given the uncertainty, any numbers are difficult to predict. European firms may have to build up their subsidiaries in London. This could act as a counterbalance.

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/what-you-need-to-know-about-brexit-and-finance/feed/ 0 Online Fashion: Strong Growth, But Can It Make Money? http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/online-fashion-strong-growth-but-can-it-make-money/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/online-fashion-strong-growth-but-can-it-make-money/#comments Thu, 12 May 2016 12:57:43 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49548 [wsj-responsive-image P="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ558_zaland_P_20160512091211.jpg" J="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ558_zaland_J_20160512091211.jpg" M="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ558_zaland_M_20160512091211.jpg" caption="Zalando labels on items of clothing at one of the company's showrooms in Berlin." credit="Reuters" placement="Header" suppressEnlarge="false" ]

Nobody doubts the growth potential of online fashion. But profits are another matter.

Zalando, Europe’s largest online fashion retailer by sales, turned just 2.5% of its sales into adjusted operating profit in the first quarter, down from 4.5% in the same period last year.

The shares plunged Thursday, even though the company had guided towards the most important numbers in April. Analysts had been expecting a better gross margin, whereas Zalando hit guidance by containing distribution and marketing costs.

[wsj-responsive-matterhorn-chart id=0]

Like H&M and Inditex, the Berlin-based retailer has been wrestling with the dollar’s strength against the euro, which pushes up purchasing costs in Southeast Asia. Management also blames the weather: the mild January made the autumn-winter collection hard to shift, while the cold March kept consumers from buying spring-summer wear.

But Zalando’s discounting could also reflect fierce competition. E-commerce giant Amazon is trying to scale up its clothing business. Specialists may struggle to compete in a game that is as much about logistics as sourcing.

Moreover, Zalando’s shares trade on 51 times forward earnings, according to FactSet, leaving little room for error.

This is still an immature sector with unclear margin prospects. Only invest if you can afford to take a very long-term view.

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/online-fashion-strong-growth-but-can-it-make-money/feed/ 0 European Stocks Are Cheaper Than Ever Against the U.S. – But Investors Don’t Buy It http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/european-stocks-are-cheaper-than-ever-against-the-u-s-but-investors-dont-buy-it/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/european-stocks-are-cheaper-than-ever-against-the-u-s-but-investors-dont-buy-it/#comments Thu, 12 May 2016 12:26:59 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49543 On one measure, European stocks are at their cheapest levels in comparison to U.S. stocks for at least 16 years.

But investors aren’t buying it. And they’re not buying the stocks, either.

The price to book ratio, which measures a stock’s market value compared to its total assets, is one of the yardsticks used by investors when valuing equity. Using that metric, European stocks look cheap relative to the U.S. They may even be the cheapest they’ve ever been.

For the month to date, the price to book ratio of the Stoxx Europe 600 is 38% below the S&P 500′s. That’s the largest difference since at least 1999, when data compiled by FactSet begins.

[wsj-responsive-image P="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ493_PriceB_P_20160512053213.jpg" J="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ493_PriceB_J_20160512053213.jpg" M="//si.wsj.net/public/resources/images/BN-NZ493_PriceB_M_20160512053213.jpg" caption="" credit="" placement="Inline" suppressEnlarge="false" ]

But investors aren’t convinced.

In one sign, this year has seen the largest continuous outflows from European exchange traded funds since the industry was getting started in 2008, according to a research note published by UBS on Thursday.

ETFs covering Europe, excluding the U.K, have seen an outflow of $10 billion since January, which UBS attributes to the continent’s miserable outlook for profits.

“No one believes Europe’s profit picture will change or that its sector profit gaps with the US will close,” said the note. “If they did, the gap would not be at all-time low.”

UBS adjusted its analysis to take into account the differing size of sectors in Europe and the U.S. 

Price to book ratios are based on the assets a company currently holds. Market capitalization, in contrast, reflects expected future earnings.

Forecasts of earnings per share in Europe over the next 12 months have declined again this year.  Over the last five years they have moved further apart from profit expectations for S&P 500 companies.

Since May, 2011, the earnings per share expected from S&P 500 companies over the next 12 months have risen by 17.3%. In Europe, expected EPS for the Stoxx 600 has declined by 11.3%.

Unless the picture for profits changes dramatically, European stocks are likely to stay looking cheap on a price to book basis, and investors are still likely to steer clear.

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/european-stocks-are-cheaper-than-ever-against-the-u-s-but-investors-dont-buy-it/feed/ 0 WSJ City: UK Housing Market Cools, The 100-Year Bet http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/wsj-city-uk-housing-market-cools-the-100-year-bet/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/wsj-city-uk-housing-market-cools-the-100-year-bet/#comments Thu, 12 May 2016 06:46:37 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49517 Good morning from London. Here’s essential reading today from WSJ City: 

George Osborne has said Treasury and BOE officials are engaged in intense Brexit contingency planning.

The UK housing market cooled in April amid uncertainty over the referendum, according to RICS.

Firms and governments are increasingly borrowing at longer maturities in Europe.

City Talk: ITV revenue rises; Zurich Insurance profit falls; Daily Mail names new CEO.

For some time Goldman Sachs was one of the biggest bears on gold. But now the bank is warming to the metal.

Few are surprised that the O2-Three deal is dead. But it does change things in the European telco space.

Are investors not buying the comeback? They’re certainly not snapping up cheap European stocks.

Empty-seated. Investment bankers have been missing out on boardroom invites to advise on big M&A deals.

Brexit backers have raised more cash from donors than those campaigning to stay in the EU.

UK police said they seized $22 million following a probe into the alleged use of a futures market to launder money.

Deutsche Börse’s Carsten Kengeter said that a tie-up with the LSE makes sense, even in the event of a Brexit.

Download WSJ City for iPhone here. 

In the Papers: 

The government wants to make Tata Steel more attractive to potential suitors by ring-fencing the pension fund and cutting its long-term liabilities by £2.5 billion. FT (£)

David Cameron is due to detail measures Britain is taking to increase transparency as he hosts an anticorruption summit in London on Thursday, even as it emerged that two of the world’s most high-profile tax havens, Panama and the British Virgin Islands, said they hadn’t been invited to participate. WSJ

Reform of corporate liability laws will mean banks and corporations will be held criminally responsible for employees involved in fraudulent practices, including tax evasion. The Times (£)

Nissan is looking at buying about a one-third stake in Mitsubishi Motors for $1.8 billion to become the latter company’s single largest shareholder. WSJ

Sir Philip Green has attacked the Pensions Regulator, accusing the watchdog of giving MPs “incorrect” information about the sale of BHS. The Telegraph (£)

The Asian owners of Three will try to resurrect a plan to create Britain’s largest mobile phone network despite European regulators blocking the takeover of O2. The Times (£)

The record dollar volume of collapsed US mergers and acquisitions this year will cost banks hundreds of millions of dollars in advisory fees. WSJ

Macy’s set off fresh fears about the health of the US retail sector, after the country’s largest department-store chain reported its worst quarterly sales since the recession. WSJ

Airbus wants to become a major player in the fast-growing global drone industry, after years of missteps by the European plane maker that have left rivals with the upper hand. WSJ

What to Expect From the Markets: 

London’s benchmark index faces opening losses on Thursday after weak US earnings sparked renewed fears about the health of the world’s biggest economy.

For months, analysts and investors have been hoping for a broad-based revival in spending that could propel the US economy, as consumers saved money at the petrol pump and the job market improved. But consumer spending has decelerated for three quarters in a row, and the economy grew just 0.5% in the first quarter.

On Wednesday, the Dow recorded its worst fall since February 11, ending the session 1.2% lower. Broad-based losses in Asian markets added to the gloom. In commodities, oil prices lost traction on profit-taking after a sharp rise in New York, driven by the unexpected drop in US crude stockpiles and continuing supply outages in Canada and Africa. Brent was 33 cents lower but still above $47 a barrel.

Stocks to Watch:  Daily Mail & General CEO Martin Morgan to retire; Paul Zwillenberg named replacement; AstraZeneca: Selumetinib granted orphan drug designation in the US; OFGEM opens mid-period review into price controls for National Grid.

Coming Up: The Bank of England announces its latest decision on interest rates. It also publishes its quarterly inflation report and the minutes of the Monetary Policy Committee’s meeting, while Mark Carney attends a press conference.

WSJ City Event: Come and hear top investors discuss navigating turbulent markets at WSJ City’s first panel discussion, on June 9 at The News Building, next to The Shard, from 7am. Sign up here.

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/12/wsj-city-uk-housing-market-cools-the-100-year-bet/feed/ 0 Oil Bust Gives Billionaire Buyer’s Remorse — Energy Journal http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/11/oil-bust-gives-billionaire-buyers-remorse-energy-journal/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/11/oil-bust-gives-billionaire-buyers-remorse-energy-journal/#comments Wed, 11 May 2016 10:51:50 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49499 Here’s your morning jolt of news, insight and analysis on the global energy business. Send us tips, suggestions and complaints: EnergyJournal@wsj.com

Sign up for this newsletter: http://on.wsj.com/EnergyJournalSignup

WILLIAMS COS. REFUSES TO LET GO OF ENERGY TRANSFER EQUITY DEAL

Energy Transfer Equity LP is scrambling to restructure or escape a $33 billion deal to buy Williams Cos. as low oil prices spread pain through the energy industry, Liz Hoffman and Alison Sider report. The deal is one of the largest announced last year and would create a 100,000-mile network of pipelines, but Energy Transfer Chairman Kelcy Warren is suffering from a severe case of buyer’s remorse.

Mr. Warren has overseen a series of moves that could end the biggest purchase of his life, such as an unusual convertible preferred share issue that would increase his own stake in the combined company.

GAZPROM GAS CONTRACTS LIFT E.ON PROFIT

German energy company E.ON SE’s  said mounting costs related to nuclear waste storage  could hurt financing and possibly trigger a capital increase, Monica Houston-Waesch reports. The company may have to pay as much as €10 billion ($11.4 billion) into a state fund to manage nuclear waste. The energy company also said net profit rose in the first quarter following a deal on natural gas contracts with Gazprom, Monica Houston-Waesch report. Earnings were slightly lower than a year earlier when stripped of the effects of the Gazprom deal.

E.ON gains from gas and newly-commissioned power plants were partially offset by low market prices. In fact, German power prices on Sunday went negative for a few hours due to abundant renewable energy, so commercial customers were being paid to consume electricity, Quartz reports.

Solar stocks have been falling sharply this year, and a weak earnings report by SolarCity Corp. didn’t help, Ben Eisen reports. SolarCity shares dropped sharply after the company reported another larger-than-expected loss and cut its installation forecast, Ezequiel Minaya reports.

ALBERTA OIL-SANDS OUTPUT SEEN RESUMING SOON

In Alberta, Premier Rachel Notley said she expects oil-sands companies that suspended output of crude oil by up to one million barrels a day due to wildfires to resume production “in the coming days and weeks,” Elena Cherney and David George-Cosh report.

In Brazil, lawmakers were ready to cast their votes to suspend President Dilma Rousseff from office despite last-minute attempts to derail the impeachment process, likely ending 13 years of rule by her leftist Workers’ Party, Paulo Trevisani reports. Economic growth may be set to pick up in Brazil in the coming months, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Paul Hannon reports.

MARKETS

Oil prices fell Wednesday after an industry group reported a higher-than-expected increase in U.S. crude stockpiles, extending recent volatility in the market.

The American Petroleum Institute reported an increase of 3.4 million barrels in U.S. crude stocks for last week. The U.S. Energy Information Administration will release its data later Wednesday and analysts surveyed by The Wall Street Journal expect the figures to show a 400,000-barrel increase in U.S. inventories last week.

Read our latest market report at wsj.com.

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/11/oil-bust-gives-billionaire-buyers-remorse-energy-journal/feed/ 0 WSJ City: Man Group Goes Back to Uni to Study Machine Learning, Barratt Boosted by Help to Buy http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/11/wsj-city-man-group-goes-back-to-uni-to-study-machine-learning-barratt-boosted-by-help-to-buy/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/11/wsj-city-man-group-goes-back-to-uni-to-study-machine-learning-barratt-boosted-by-help-to-buy/#comments Wed, 11 May 2016 06:50:34 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49480 Good morning from London. Here’s essential reading today from WSJ City: 

Man Group is changing the focus of an Oxford University department it funds to machine learning.

Shareholder discontent hits Shell. Investors have been urged to reject its pay plans later this month.

City Talk: Barratt Developments sees strong market, Compass profit rises, Experian plans share buyback.

Bank league tables can be a surprisingly thorny issue. Cut the right way, anyone can be number one.

As Sadiq Khan becomes London’s new mayor, there’s another surprise winner: Tube bondholders.

Whisper it quietly, but this summer might not be marked by a flare-up of the Greek crisis.

Dividend yields appear to bolster the case for buying stocks now. But other metrics tell a different story.

easyJet’s Carolyn McCall will be watching to see if terrorism fears are causing holidaymakers to hold back.

Hotel Chocolat appeared to hit an investor sweet spot on its first day of trading. Shares rose more than 30%

Eric Varvel, a former head of Credit Suisse’s investment bank, is to head its asset management business.

Credit Suisse got a boost from an unexpected source in the first quarter: a collapse in its own shares.

Monetary policy is ‘reaching the limits’ of what it can do, the head of a central bank has warned.

Goldman Sachs and Jefferies have stopped buying LendingClub loans, potentially delaying large deals.

Facebook has denied claims that it suppressed ‘trending’ news about conservative issues.

Download WSJ City for iPhone here. 

In the Papers: 

Five bidders submitted offers for BHS before Tuesday’s final deadline, raising hopes that a white knight investor will save the retailer. The Times (£)

London’s office development has hit a 20-year high, according to new a report, with 51 projects currently under construction. The Telegraph

The Cayman Islands said the offshore tax register backed by David Cameron as part of his  transparency drive is “pointless.” FT (£)

The UK’s biggest housebuilders have signed an agreement to increase their output significantly and make it easier to trade land, after coming under pressure from the government. FT (£)

Alberta’s premier said she expects oil-sands companies that suspended output of crude oil by up to one million barrels a day due to wildfires that ravaged the Fort McMurray area in Canada to resume production “in the coming days and weeks.” WSJ

A federal judge has blocked the planned merger of rivals Staples and Office Depot because of antitrust concerns, prompting the office-supply companies to say they would abandon the roughly $6 billion deal. WSJ

Disney’s earnings rose a weaker-than-expected 1.7%, helped by its recent film success but hurt in part by lower ad revenue at ESPN. WSJ

What to Expect From the Markets: 

Shares in London are poised for minor opening losses on Wednesday after oil prices fell back following gains on Tuesday. Crude edged lower in Asia as investors weighed reports that the production outages in Canada following the Alberta wildfires may end soon. Shell’s Canadian unit said it was able to restart production at its Albian mine, which it suspended on May 3, marking the first major producer to resume operations since the fires started.

Stocks to Watch: Compass 1H net profit £500m, full year views positive and unchanged; Experian full year pretax profot $1.03bn, Expects mid single-digit organic rev growth in fiscal 2017; TUI 1H Underlying EBITA Loss €236.9; Barratt Developments market conditions remain strong.

Coming Up: The Office for National Statistics issues industrial production data for March, while the NIESR’s Monthly GDP Estimates and National Institute Economic Review are released; MPs quiz the Chancellor as part of their inquiry into the economic and financial costs and benefits of the UK’s EU membership

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/11/wsj-city-man-group-goes-back-to-uni-to-study-machine-learning-barratt-boosted-by-help-to-buy/feed/ 0 Saudi Arabian Fight for Oil Market Intensifies — Energy Journal http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/10/saudi-arabian-fight-for-oil-market-intensifies-energy-journal/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/10/saudi-arabian-fight-for-oil-market-intensifies-energy-journal/#comments Tue, 10 May 2016 10:48:39 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49462 Here’s your morning jolt of news, insight and analysis on the global energy business. Send us tips, suggestions and complaints: EnergyJournal@wsj.com

Sign up for this newsletter: http://on.wsj.com/EnergyJournalSignup

SAUDI ARABIA LOOKS BEYOND OIL

Saudi Arabia’s economic battle over the oil market with Iran, Russia and others is intensifying even as it attempts to reduce its dependence on oil, Benoit Faucon, Selina Williams and Summer Said report. Officials with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, or OPEC, say the contest won’t settle down until geopolitical rifts in the Middle East cool.

Saudi Arabia’s rivalry with Iran has contributed to violent conflicts in Syria and Yemen and made it nearly impossible for OPEC to agree on tactics to raise crude prices. Russia has managed to keep its European market share steady in 2014 and 2015, while Saudi Arabia has slipped.

Meanwhile, Saudi Arabian Oil Co., known as Saudi Aramco, plans to nearly double its gas production in 10 years, Chief Executive Amin Nasser said. Saudi Aramco will continue to expand and is eyeing opportunities abroad, Bill Spindle and Summer Said report Mr. Nasser as saying.

Analysts got over the news of Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi being ousted as they focused on the Alberta wildfires, Spencer Jakab writes, but some context is necessary since he already was headed for retirement.

Still, the revamped energy ministry is one of the five key areas of the kingdom’s reshuffle, the Financial Times reports.

OIL-WORKER HOUSING AN ISSUE AMID ALBERTA FIRES

Reporters got the first public look at Fort McMurray in Alberta since the fires swept through, forcing the hasty evacuation of 80,000 residents, Chester Dawson reports. Seeing the devastation “was really quite overwhelming in some spots,” Alberta Premier Rachel Notley said after touring the town.

She said one of the issues she would discuss with energy executives is housing for oil-sands workers subject to evacuation orders, some of whom have lost their homes. Fort McMurray and much of the surrounding area are inaccessible to workers in the oil-sands industry, and many oil producers have reduced their crude output, with at least 645,000 barrels a day now cut, more than a quarter of daily production.

SHELL EVACUATES NON-ESSENTIAL STAFF FROM NIGERIA FIELD

Royal Dutch Shell PLC evacuated nonessential staff from one of its Nigerian oil fields amid mounting militancy in the country’s oil-rich Niger Delta region, Sarah Kent reports. The move follows an attack on one of Chevron Corp.’s offshore facilities last week that knocked out 35,000 barrels a day of the company’s oil production.

MARKETS

Oil prices gained on Tuesday, with supply outages from Canada to Nigeria helping to alleviate the global glut of crude.

Wildfires in Canada’s oil-rich Alberta province have knocked off some 1.6 million barrels a day according to consultancy Energy Aspects. Several companies including Suncor, BP, and Phillips 66 have declared force majeure on Canadian crude.

According to analysts at Commerzbank, the outages in Canada will contribute to tightening supply on the North American market and could lead to a decline in U.S. crude oil stockpiles in the coming weeks.

Read our latest market report at wsj.com.

Here’s essential reading today from WSJ City: 

Credit Suisse swung to a loss in the first quarter, as it struggles to restructure its investment bank.

easyJet reported a first-half loss after terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels slowed bookings.

Investors have raised the volume on the possible impact of Brexit as the rhetoric ramps up on both sides.

The FCA has secured two convictions as part of the largest insider trading probe in its history.

Oil, EM assets and stocks have all rallied this year. But what happens if the US dollar changes course?

Speculative investors in oil have cut their bullish bets on the price of oil for the first time in a month.

Investors are increasingly worried about the ‘crowding’ of hedge fund positions in the same stocks.

A new Swiss law on dark pools may signal how financial regulations could be looser in a post-Brexit UK.

The pound has staged a comeback against the dollar. But caution still looks like the best course.

A London-based partner and senior European securities banker at Goldman Sachs is leaving the firm.

Cantor Fitzgerald Europe’s co-CEO has quit to explore opportunities beyond investment banking.

Sotheby’s reported a larger-than-expected first-quarter loss amid a decline in net auction sales.

Negative rates could be making more of a splash than QE. Just not the way economists would expect them to.

Download WSJ City for iPhone here. 

In the Papers: 

George Osborne has warned that the City faces losing “tens of thousands” of jobs if Britain votes for Brexit. FT (£)

MPs have accused the head of the Pensions Regulator of being “toothless” after she admitted that the first her organisation knew of the sale of BHS for £1 was when it appeared in the papers. The Times (£)

India’s JSW Steel has made a late bid as one of the seven potential suitors selected by Tata for its UK assets. FT (£)

A former senior investment banker and a close personal friend of his were on Monday found guilty of insider dealing, following a three-month trial at Southwark Crown Court. WSJ City

The full privatisation of Channel 4 has been scrapped after a government intervention, although other major reforms of the state-owned broadcaster remain possible. The Telegraph

Deutsche Bank has named Patrick Campion as head of wealth management Americas to run its private-banking unit in the US, marking his return to the German bank after nine years with HSBC as chief executive of its US private bank.WSJ

Microsoft is shutting down its Chinese Web portal next month as the company shifts its focus from providing online content to offering software and services for Windows 10 devices. WSJ

What to Expect From the Markets: 

London’s blue-chip shares are forecast to open slightly higher on Tuesday despite a sharp retreat in oil prices.

Oil futures slumped in New York after reports that wildfires in Canada had slowed and moved away from key production facilities. Brent lost almost 4%, while the US benchmark ended down nearly 3%. Some traders said the fires were a more immediate factor than Saudi Arabia’s removal of its oil minister over the weekend.

Declines in commodity prices sent shares of energy and materials companies in the S&P 500 lower, while gold, silver and copper futures all fell over 2%. Brent edged lower still in Asia and was last trading at $43.61. Elsewhere in Asia, shares were choppy though the Nikkei surged after Japan’s finance minister reiterated his stance on currency intervention.

Stocks to Watch: 

Credit Suisse swings to loss; Nokia falls to surprise loss; Munich Re cuts 2016 after-tax profit guidance; easyJet 1H pretax loss £24m; Capita has solid start to 2016.
Coming Up: The Office for National Statistics issues UK trade data for March, while the REC/KPMG report on jobs is also published.

]]> http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/10/wsj-city-credit-suisse-swings-to-a-loss-bookings-slow-at-easyjet/feed/ 0 Krispy Kreme to Exit Public Markets After 16 Years of Hot and Cold http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/09/krispy-kreme-to-exit-public-markets-after-16-years-of-hot-and-cold/?mod=WSJ_moneybeat_blog http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/05/09/krispy-kreme-to-exit-public-markets-after-16-years-of-hot-and-cold/#comments Mon, 09 May 2016 14:26:50 +0000 http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/?p=49427 More than a decade ago, shares of Krispy Kreme Doughnuts were about as hot as the company’s fresh-out-of-the-oven doughnuts, which stoked lines around the block.

But the fascination wore off as the Southeast-focused chain’s goods became pervasive—along with its stores. The overexpansion landed the company in trouble, and there was some question about whether Krispy Kreme could make it through the financial crisis.

Shares, which almost got to $50 in 2003, bottomed in 2009 at $1.01. They then briefly breached $25 in late 2013 before pulling back anew amid inconsistent results.

[wsj-responsive-matterhorn-chart id=0]

Now Krispy Kreme will be able to get its act together away from the glare of the public markets. The company is set to become the latest U.S. consumer firm to come under the umbrella of German company JAB Holding Co.

For the firm—which manages the wealth of one of Germany’s wealthiest families, the Reimanns—agreeing to pay $1.35 billion for Krispy Kreme comes soon after JAB led the acquisition of Keurig Green Mountain. It goes without saying that myriad synergistic possibilities come to mind for a doughnut chain and the coffee firm and JAB’s already-owned Peet’s Coffee & Tea. It’s also apropos that Keurig has been undergoing its own hangover as its in-home brewing machines became ubiquitous.

(RELATED: Meet JAB, the German Company Buying Krispy Kreme)

But before thinking about combined Krispy Kreme-Keurig efforts, the former needs to get its house in order as sales have been slowing at international locations—which make up more than 70% of the company’s store count.

The $21-per-share price tag is a level Krispy Kreme last traded at barely a year ago; it closed Friday at $16.86.

Other JAB holdings include beauty-products maker Coty and shoemaker Jimmy Choo.
